lines.text: During the war, my husband was... Swiss.
There's nary a conspiracy. And if I'm right about this, it's a far older sin than politics.
Had a brother who went to America once. Canada, actually. Before the first German war. Suppose he's dead by now. Almost everyone is.
I protest this cruel and inhumane activity. Sir
[indistinguishable]
. don't you know the animals are your friends? Are you the master?
I am, Madame.
Then call off this wretched business. What has the fox ever done to you? Why do you persecute him?

[Imperiously]
Madame, the fox and I know more of life than you do. It is man's nature to hunt; it is the fox's to be hunted.
[Dismissively]
Good morning, Madame.
Your husband will not be alarmed that you are not at home?
My husband's dead. He was killed in Korea with the Glouchesters.
And you are a widow all this time?
Yes.
Apalling!
I beg your pardon!
I am a Frenchman, Madame. I abhor waste.

[Referring to the plane crash]
You know, according to the newspapers, there's a stromg possibility that the crash was no accident.
If there was a bomb, it would have to have been put there by a madman.
That's the excuse they usually givefor evil. Hitler was mad they said. So he may have been... but not necessarily. Evil does exict. evil IS.
[He shakes his head]

[Referrung to Brougham]
so, the masquerade is over

[sighs]
Yeah, no need for disguises now. All that ended when the last name was struck off the list. All he has to do now is be his own charming self.
What arrogance... making himself welcome at Gleneyre!
Heh, makes it easier for him to get at the boy, hmmm, from the inside. You know, I hate to admit it, but I must confess to a sneaking admiration for him.
